2:
"I truly know that this is so.\q But how can a person be in the right with God?
\q
3:
If he wants to argue with God,\q he cannot answer him once in a thousand times.


\q
4:
God is wise in heart and mighty in strength;\q who has ever hardened himself against him and succeeded?—
\q
5:
he who removes the mountains without warning anyone\q when he overturns them in his anger—
\q
6:
he who shakes the earth out of its place\q and sets its supports trembling.


\q
7:
It is the same God who tells the sun not to rise, and it does not,\q and who covers up the stars,
\q
8:
who by himself stretches out the heavens\q and tramples down the waves of the sea,
\q
9:
who makes the Bear, Orion, the Pleiades,\q and the constellations of the south.


\q
10:
He does great and unsearchable things,\q and wonderful things that cannot be counted.
\q
11:
See, he goes by me, and I do not see him;\q he passes on also, but I do not perceive him.
\q
12:
If he takes something away, who can stop him?\q Who can say to him, 'What are you doing?'


\q
13:
God will not withdraw his anger;\q the helpers of Rahab bow beneath him.
\q
14:
How much less could I answer him,\q could I choose words to reason with him?
\q
15:
Even if I were righteous, I could not answer him;\q I could only plead for mercy with my judge.


\q
16:
Even if I called and he answered me,\q I would not believe that he was listening to my voice.
\q
17:
For he breaks me with a tempest\q and multiplies my wounds without cause.
\q
18:
He does not allow me to regain my breath;\q but he fills me with bitterness.


\q
19:
If it is a matter of strength, behold, he is mighty!\q If it is a matter of justice, who can summon him?
\q
20:
Though I am in the right, my own mouth would condemn me;\q and though I am blameless, my words would prove me to be guilty.



\q
21:
I am blameless, but I do not care any more about myself;\q I despise my own life.
\q
22:
It makes no difference, which is why I say\q that he destroys blameless people and wicked people together.
\q
23:
If a plague should suddenly kill,\q he would laugh at the afflictions of innocent people.
\q
24:
The earth is given into the hand of wicked people;\q God covers the faces of its judges.
\q If it is not he who does it, then who is it?


\q
25:
My days are swifter than a running messenger;\q my days flee away; they see no good anywhere.
\q
26:
They are as fast as papyrus reed boats,\q and as fast as the eagle that swoops down on its victim.


\q
27:
If I said that I would forget about my complaints,\q that I would take off my sad face and be happy,
\q
28:
I would be afraid of all my sorrows\q because I know that you will not consider me innocent.
\q
29:
I will be condemned;\q why, then, should I try in vain?


\q
30:
If I washed myself with snow water\q and made my hands ever so clean,
\q
31:
God would plunge me in a ditch,\q and my own clothes would be disgusted with me.


\q
32:
For God is not a man, as I am, that I could answer him,\q that we could come together in court.
\q
33:
There is no judge between us\q who might lay his hand upon us both.


\q
34:
There is no other judge who could take God's rod off me,\q who could keep his terror from frightening me.
\q
35: Then would I speak up and not fear him.\q But as things are now, I cannot do that.
